p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: -0.8862in; margin-right: 0in; margin-top: 0in; margin-bottom: 0.0417in; text-align: end; text-indent: 0.8862in; color: #0000ff;

div.p: MS 58 (044) MUE, Herbarium of Western Australia, Perth.

Proofed.*This might be 3 letters.
Most probably 1893 based on collection dates. See notes below
.
[…]
The first page of MS has 'No. 4' pencilled at top.

cell.style: padding-left: 0.0556in; padding-right: 0.0556in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
padding-left: 0.0556in; padding-right: 0.0556in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
padding-left: 0.0556in; padding-right: 0.0556in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
padding-left: 0.0556in; padding-right: 0.0556in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
cell.p:
Logania leptomeroides
HC: no such species; possibly L. choretroides.
FvM

Of this rare plant I have received twice from near the sources of Swan-River female flowering plants. Yours are the first males received by me. The fruit remains yet to be discovered so that the position of the plant in the genus Logania is not yet finally affirmed. Could you procure also specimens with ripe
fruit (probably small seed vessels) Are the flowers fragrant?

cell.style: padding-left: 0.0556in; padding-right: 0.0556in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
padding-left: 0.0556in; padding-right: 0.0556in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
padding-left: 0.0556in; padding-right: 0.0556in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
padding-left: 0.0556in; padding-right: 0.0556in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
cell.p: To name this species, it would be necessary to press some loose and open flowers into a book for drying, also to get fruit

cell.style: padding-left: 0.0556in; padding-right: 0.0556in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
padding-left: 0.0556in; padding-right: 0.0556in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;

padding-left: 0.0556in; padding-right: 0.0556in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
cell.p:
Chara.
HC: this is an algal genus.

cell.style: padding-left: 0.0556in; padding-right: 0.0556in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
padding-left: 0.0556in; padding-right: 0.0556in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
padding: 0in; border: none;
padding-left: 0.0556in; padding-right: 0.0556in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
padding-left: 0.0556in; padding-right: 0.0556in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
padding-left: 0.0556in; padding-right: 0.0556in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
padding-left: 0.0556in; padding-right: 0.0556in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
cell.p: Could specimens of this with ripe seeds be obtained

cell.style: padding-left: 0.0556in; padding-right: 0.0556in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
padding-left: 0.0556in; padding-right: 0.0556in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
cell.p:
The small-flowered Eucalyptus, of which you sent sprigs this time is E. microtheca FvM. I should like some seeds for sowing It is new for W.A . and this will be recorded under your honored name
Eponymy 2 only has Hemigenia Tysoni, 1893.

cell.style: padding-left: 0.0556in; padding-right: 0.0556in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
padding-left: 0.0556in; padding-right: 0.0556in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;

padding-left: 0.0556in; padding-right: 0.0556in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
padding-left: 0.0556in; padding-right: 0.0556in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
padding-left: 0.0556in; padding-right: 0.0556in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
padding-left: 0.0556in; padding-right: 0.0556in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
cell.p: Are other species of Misletoe growing on the trees there?

cell.style: padding-left: 0.0556in; padding-right: 0.0556in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
padding-left: 0.0556in; padding-right: 0.0556in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
cell.p: This handsome species was only once before found, (on the Gascoyne-River) Could seeds later be got?

cell.style: padding-left: 0.0556in; padding-right: 0.0556in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;

padding-left: 0.0556in; padding-right: 0.0556in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
cell.p: Of many species of Acacia of your region the ripe fruits are totally unknown yet

cell.style: padding-left: 0.0556in; padding-right: 0.0556in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
padding-left: 0.0556in; padding-right: 0.0556in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
cell.p:
Cynanchum floribundum, RBrown
collecting date either 1890 or 1896.

cell.style: padding-left: 0.0556in; padding-right: 0.0556in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
padding-left: 0.0556in; padding-right: 0.0556in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
cell.p: Ripe fruit also required Many Swainsonas are poisonous You must have more than one there

cell.style: padding-left: 0.0556in; padding-right: 0.0556in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
padding-left: 0.0556in; padding-right: 0.0556in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
padding-left: 0.0556in; padding-right: 0.0556in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
padding-left: 0.0556in; padding-right: 0.0556in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
cell.p:
Peplidium
collecting date is definitely 1896.
From here on only two specimens are on MELISR and dated 1894. For others either not on database or impossible to tell which might possibilities.

cell.style: padding-left: 0.0556in; padding-right: 0.0556in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
padding-left: 0.0556in; padding-right: 0.0556in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
cell.p: This I must carefully examine. Can you send more.

cell.style: padding-left: 0.0556in; padding-right: 0.0556in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
padding-left: 0.0556in; padding-right: 0.0556in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
cell.p: If this is the Chenopodium auricomum, then it is a good spinage-plant

cell.style: padding-left: 0.0556in; padding-right: 0.0556in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
padding-left: 0.0556in; padding-right: 0.0556in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
padding-left: 0.0556in; padding-right: 0.0556in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;

p.style: font-family: Geneva; margin-left: 0.3335in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.3335in; font-size: 9pt;
p.seg: might the following be a different letter from that above? It starts on a new page. But the text continues beneath the list.

cell.style: padding-left: 0.0556in; padding-right: 0.0556in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;

padding-left: 0.0556in; padding-right: 0.0556in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;

div.p:
It was a pleasing surprise to me, dear Mr Tyson, to receive your sending, and I trust you will continue to dry and press flowering and also seeding specimens for me in the excellent manner, which you have adopted. But not only the showy kinds are desired, — also minute weeds floating plants, salt bushes,
'minute' and 'salt' probably underlined by Tyson, not M. indeed anything, as the geographic distribution of the various sorts has to be much further yet traced in your region and elsewhere in Western Australia

cell.style: padding-left: 0.0556in; padding-right: 0.0556in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
padding-left: 0.0556in; padding-right: 0.0556in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
padding-left: 0.0556in; padding-right: 0.0556in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
padding-left: 0.0556in; padding-right: 0.0556in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
cell.p: one of the three "Sneeze-Weeds" of Australia. First now by you sent from WA.

cell.style: padding-left: 0.0556in; padding-right: 0.0556in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
padding-left: 0.0556in; padding-right: 0.0556in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
cell.p: Probably Exocarpos aphylla RBr but no good flowers nor fruits on the specimen.

cell.style: padding-left: 0.0556in; padding-right: 0.0556in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
padding-left: 0.0556in; padding-right: 0.0556in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;

div.p: Let me hope, dear Mr Tyson, that you will soon have rain and plenty of it. Doubtless in course of time may artesian wells will be sunk, the water of which will be also then utilized for surface storage

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 1.75in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0in;
font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 1.75in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0in;
font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 1.75in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0in;

div.p: I suppose, you have a leading interest in the station there
